Award.AwardTitle: Spatial Population Dynamics in Streams or Rivers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spatial population dynamics and invasions of species in streams and rivers have attracted increasing scientific scrutiny. The purpose of this project is to understand effects of the water flow and inter- and intra- relations in species on population spread and persistence in streams or rivers that may be subject to temporal and spatial variations. Reaction-diffusion-advection equations and integro-difference / differential equations will be studied. Researchers will investigate effects of temporal and spatial heterogeneity on spreading speeds and/or persistence conditions for a single species and for multiple species in different river environments. The relation among hydrological factors of a real river will be incorporated into population models. The optimal control and observer theory will be combined to spatial dynamics theory to study influences of global perturbations of parameters on population invasions of an invasive species.

Real rivers or streams can never be ideally homogeneous everywhere at all times. It is crucial to introduce temporal and spatial heterogeneity and hydrological relations into population models. It is also interesting to combine the optimal control and observer theory and invasion dynamics. Researchers will derive reliable predictions about influences of the water flow and physical river conditions on population dynamics and provide suggestions on Instream Flow Needs, biological invasion control, river channel design, and water resource management. The following questions could be answered based on the study: How does the total annual flow discharge influence the ecosystem health? Is it better to have fluctuating flows or a constant flow for population persistence? How much water can we take from a river without destroying the ecosystem? How much spatial heterogeneity should be kept for healthy ecosystem while designing a river channel? Will a species be persistent or extinct in a specific real river? How to control an invasive species in a river? More questions than these are likely to be addressed as the project progresses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on spatial population dynamics and invasions in streams or rivers, by virtue of deriving persistence conditions and invasion speeds for river species and investigating influences of biological features and environmental conditions on these quantities or conditions. It aims to take into account realistic river environments and species interactions in mathematical modelling in order to provide reasonable predictions or suggestions on population persistence or extinction, invasion control, river channel design, and water resource managements.

Spatial and temporal heterogeneity is introduced into population models to avoid oversimplification of assuming homogeneous or simple piecewise habitats, while this leads to requirement of enriching theories for continuous-time and/or discrete-time models with varying parameters. Two types of threshold quantities are used to describe population persistence in the habitat. One is the principal eigenvalue of the eigenvalue problem associated to the linearized system at a steady state; the other one is the net reproductive rate that relates to the lifetime reproductive output of a species and is defined through the next generation operator mapping the population forward in time from one generation to the next. We establish persistence thresholds for a single species in complex river networks of tree structures, in a periodic meandering river consisting of a main channel and favorable point bars, and in one-dimensional and two-dimensional rivers that consist of a benthic zone and a drift zone as significantly different sub-habitats. We also investigate the persistence and coexistence of competitive species and predator-prey systems in a homogeneous habitat or in a temporally and/or spatially varying benthic-drift habitat. In the perspective of biological invasions and control, we derive the predator-invasion speeds and the prey-spread speeds for a predator-prey model in an advective habitat; we also investigate the influence of demographic and control parameters on spreading speeds of a stage-structured invasive (or pest) population in temporally constant and fluctuating environments.

Mathematical results in this project extend existing theories in spatial dynamics and invasion speeds for partial differential equation systems and integro-difference equation systems. In particular, new fundamental theories of parabolic and elliptic problems in complex domains with interface and boundary conditions are established. Hydrological relations are coupled into population models to describe real situations in rivers and to predict reliable results about effects of physical and hydrological conditions, together with biotic factors, on long-term population dynamics and invasions for single and interacting species. Numerical methods for calculation of persistence thresholds and invasion speeds are applicable to ecologists and river engineers who expect to determine whether a species can persist or not in a given river (system) or how to control an invasive (or pest) species.

The grant has successfully supported publication of research papers, training of undergraduate and graduate students, conference attendance and research communications.
